triples.name: Boolean satisfiability problem
triples.relevance: SAT is the central problem discussed in the handbook as the key enabling technology for automated verification.

triples.name: Boolean expression
triples.relevance: Boolean formulas are fundamental components of the SAT problem and its applications in verification.

triples.name: Model checking
triples.relevance: Model checking is a primary application domain for SAT solvers in hardware and software verification.

triples.name: Model checking
triples.relevance: Bounded model checking is described as a key SAT-based technique for practical verification of systems.

triples.name: Linear temporal logic
triples.relevance: LTL is used to express specifications in bounded model checking of sequential circuits.

triples.name: Decision problem
triples.relevance: Decision procedures are core techniques used alongside SAT solvers for program verification.

triples.name: Bit array
triples.relevance: Bit-vector decision procedures are used in program verification for handling finite word-length integers.

triples.name: Formal verification
triples.relevance: Automated verification of computer hardware and software is the primary application driver for SAT solver power.

triples.name: Combinatorial optimization
triples.relevance: Combinatorial optimization is one of the applied areas connected to SAT solving mentioned in the paper.

triples.name: Job-shop scheduling
triples.relevance: Scheduling is identified as one of the applied areas where SAT-related techniques are applied.
